#Text=3. Smart Campus/University Communications Architectures

#Text=Several authors have previously proposed different smart campus architectures , but it can be stated that , in general , they can be classified as Service-Oriented Architecture ( SOA ) architectures that revolve around two main paradigms ( IoT and cloud computing ) , which are usually helped by Big Data when processing and analyzing the collected information .

#Text=An example of smart campus architecture based on cloud computing is presented in , where the authors deployed a smart campus platform in three months by using Commercial Off-The-Shelf ( COTS ) hardware and Microsoft Azure cloud services .
#Text=With respect to IoT , its use has been proposed for easing the deployment of architectures that allow for implementing learning , access control , or resource water management applications .
#Text=Some researchers have also proposed alternative paradigms for creating smart campuses .
#Text=For instance , the authors of propose an opportunistic communications architecture that allows for sharing data through infrastructure-less services .

#Text=The main novelty behind the proposed architecture is the concept of Floating Content node , which is a computing device that produces data that can be shared among users located in nearby areas .
#Text=Similar architectures have been proposed , but they have been focused on improving certain aspects like security .

#Text=Some of the latest smart campus architectures have suggested the use of the different types of the edge computing paradigm ( e.g. , mobile edge computing or fog computing ) , which have already been successfully applied to other smart fields .

#Text=The main advantage of edge computing is its ability to offload part of the processing tasks from the cloud , delegating such tasks to the so-called edge devices , which are physically located close to the IoT nodes .
#Text=Thanks to this approach , the amount of communications transactions with the cloud and latency response are reduced , while also being able to provide location-aware services .
#Text=For example , the authors of make use of edge computing devices to improve their smart campus architecture .
#Text=Such devices are focused on delivering services related to content caching and bandwidth allocation .
#Text=A similar approach is presented in , where the researchers provide smart campus services through edge computing devices embedded into street lights .

#Text=In the case of the work detailed in , the authors propose a smart campus platform called WiCloud that is based in mobile edge computing , which allows for accessing the platform servers through mobile phone base stations or wireless access points .
#Text=Finally , it is worth mentioning the smart campus system presented in , which makes use of fog computing nodes to enhance user experience .
#Text=To clarify the previously mentioned architectures ,
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=illustrates their evolution .
#Text=In this figure , at the top , the traditional cloud-based architecture is depicted , which is composed by two main layers :
#Text=Node layer : it consists of multiple IoT nodes and computing devices , whose data are collected through IoT gateways and routers in order to send them to the cloud where they are stored .
#Text=Cloud layer : it is essentially a central server or a group of servers where the main processing tasks are carried out .

#Text=In addition , the cloud allows for interacting with third parties , it presents the stored data to remote users and enables interconnecting the multiple IoT networks that may be scattered through different physical locations .
#Text=The architecture depicted at the bottom of
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=on the left represents a fog computing architecture .
#Text=In this case , besides the node layer and the cloud , there is a third layer ( the fog layer ) , which is made of fog devices .
#Text=Such devices provide different local fog services to the IoT nodes and are also able to exchange data among them to collaborate in certain tasks .

#Text=A fog computing device is usually implemented on a Single-Board Computer ( SBC ) , which is essentially a reduced-size low-cost computer ( e.g. , Raspberry Pi and Orange Pi PC ) that can be easily deployed in the campus facilities .
#Text=Finally , the third and more evolved architecture of
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=is the one at the bottom , on the right , which illustrates a typical edge computing smart campus architecture .

#Text=Such an architecture is basically an enhanced version of the previously mentioned fog computing-based architecture , but through its edge computing layer it provides more computing power , thanks to the use of cloudlets .
#Text=A cloudlet is often a high-end computer that is able to perform compute-intensive tasks , like the ones related to complex data processing or image rendering .
